body:
> What a thorough update! I can tell there was some complexity with what to name this thing. EnvironmentRegistry. EnvSystemRegistry. EnvironmentSystemRegistry, etc.. I recommend we just consistently call this thing ENVIRONMENT as the scope like you did then just use the term Environment everywhere else. Define this scope as providing values in the order of JVM System Properties first then Environment variables available to the process and just leave it referred to as 'Environment'. What do you think?

+1 for `ENVIRONMENT` as the name of the scope going forward.
Hey @exceptionfactory - I've some concerns around the HL7 bundle, while it's not been updated/changed in a long time, I believe we have quite a few users using NiFi and the HL7 processors.

Thanks for the feedback @pvillard31, I reverted the HL7 bundle removal for this pull request.

The Route and Extract HL7 Processors read the entire FlowFile content into memory for parsing, to accommodate the requirements of the HAPI library, which is not optimal. It would probably be better to implement new components that support writing Records instead of FlowFile attributes, but we could consider these questions in a separate Jira issue.

Yeah definitely agree that having better HL7 capabilities (as a Record Reader for example) would make a lot of sense. Thanks for reverting the removal of this bundle. I can merge the PR a bit later today.

Yeah, sorry about that @exceptionfactory I did push without running through all of the system tests. I ran only the ones that I thought were affected, but I've updated the PR and ensured that all pass now. 
Also - good call on the support line. I had overlooked that. But there are a few things different between the two, so I think it's best to leave this PR as-is and generate a new PR for the support line. I'll push up a new PR for that one in a bit.

Actually @exceptionfactory nevermind about the support branch - this fix does not need to go to the support branch, as it affects 2.0 only. The issue is in the StatelessBasicsIT, which tests running a Process Group using the Stateless Execution Engine. So it does not apply to the 1.x line.

> Actually @exceptionfactory nevermind about the support branch - this fix does not need to go to the support branch, as it affects 2.0 only. The issue is in the StatelessBasicsIT, which tests running a Process Group using the Stateless Execution Engine. So it does not apply to the 1.x line.

Good point, thanks @markap14!

@exceptionfactory if you're close to merging go ahead but i'm doing a local build and will also run sys tests. Github CI looks great so at this point we're clear to fire.  I'll take it unless you're already done

> @exceptionfactory if you're close to merging go ahead but i'm doing a local build and will also run sys tests. Github CI looks great so at this point we're clear to fire. I'll take it unless you're already done

Thanks @joewitt, the system test changes themselves look good, but I just noted that JavaScript UI code changes are also necessary to align with renaming the enum values.
Thanks @exceptionfactory just realized that I didn't push that change. Will push another commit in one moment

> Thanks @exceptionfactory just realized that I didn't push that change. Will push another commit in one moment

Thanks for the quick turnaround @markap14, that looks like that should cover the necessary changes. I will wait for one more system test run and then plan to merge!
@exceptionfactory sorry i was already well into this.  merged to main!

> @exceptionfactory sorry i was already well into this. merged to main!

No problem, latest run looks good, thanks @joewitt and @markap14!

This should work since the top-level `convert()` is for each RecordField in the Record, but shouldn't we have the null checks in the individual `convert()s` too just in case `convert()` is called directly from somewhere else? Or do we trust in having the Record/Map/Array converters call the new method (I'm calling it `convertWithNullCheck()`)?
@pvillard31 you mind rebasing given the changes?  What do you think about getting rid of the EnvSys naming and just referring to it uniformly as EnvironmentVariables instead?
I'll push a commit with the new method and change the complex types to call that, just for safety :)

Build is good but we need L&N.

For the slack lib added it is at least: https://github.com/SlackAPI/java-slack-sdk/blob/main/LICENSE

That will need to be in nifi-assembly/LICENSE as it is MIT.

Looking at transitive deps and will provide more
I also think these libs pull in some rather dated libraries.  We should likely override them to their newer counterparts as the CVE nature of these is often considerable.  Looking in depth now

> I also think these libs pull in some rather dated libraries. We should likely override them to their newer counterparts as the CVE nature of these is often considerable. Looking in depth now

Thanks for looking into this @joewitt, we should definitely override to the latest versions of items whenever we can, especially when introducing new libraries.
should bump to slack lib 1.32.1

@MikeThomsen Wanted to ping and see if you're able to get this one wrapped up?  Seems good to get it done.  Probably makes sense as 'main/2.x only'.  As we close in on 2x i am less inclined to make changes to defaults like this on the 1x/support line but others views may differ.

-1
@dan-s1 this is a super common format that we don't want to consider invalid. While I do think it's reasonable to have the option to consider that invalid, we should not be changing the behavior like this. I'd be fine with adding a property to the processor to make it optional, though.
@dan-s1 it is basically this https://jsonlines.org/ and it is super weirdly common in the wild so at this point while it isn't valid JSON is valid 'JSON Lines'.  We need to keep supporting it.

Thanks for thoroughly reviewing @exceptionfactory . I'll plan on reviewing this in more depth next week as well. In the meantime, I do agree with your comment above re: deleting the antiquated integration tests.

> Thanks for thoroughly reviewing @exceptionfactory . I'll plan on reviewing this in more depth next week as well. In the meantime, I do agree with your comment above re: deleting the antiquated integration tests.

Thanks for the confirmation on the integration tests @markap14!
The problem though without my change the ObjectMapper only reads the first object in the incoming file and validates against that.  I wouldn't think that is the correct behavior either.

> That warning will apparently be resolved in the next amazon-kinesis-client version: [awslabs/amazon-kinesis-client#745](https://github.com/awslabs/amazon-kinesis-client/issues/745)

Fix included in KCL 2.5.1, we're upgrading to 2.5.2 here 👍

> I agree it's not worth delaying this PR for the sake of the already flakey ITs. If one doesn't already exist, could you raise a Jira to investigate further/fix, maybe along with using TestContainers to launch LocalStack and run everything in a consistent environment?

Good idea: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/NIFI-12119

> The problem though without my change the ObjectMapper only reads the first object in the incoming file and validates against that. I wouldn't think that is the correct behavior either.

So what we could do with is some sort of `ValidateJsonRecord` then, i.e. use a `JsonTreeReader` to iterate through all JSON Objects within a FlowFile, then validate each of those and output the results. `ValidateRecord` would be a pattern to consider following here, just that we'll be applying the JSON Schema validation rather than the Avro Schema validation currently used by `ValidateRecord`

@joewitt  -- I have cleanup the integration test. There is technically a way to use it with janusgraph-core in memory and convert it to an actual unit test, but it will require this to have a lot of O&M to continue working as new version of groovy/gremlin/java come out. I would recommend leaving it as a simple IT. I have added documentation on how to run it, and someone knowledgeable about this process would be able to run it. 

I have also squashed all the commits. Let me know if you have any other changes you would like to add to this!

The resulting image grew from 1.7GB to 2.2GB.  Most of this is from the inclusion of Python3 which we'll want so users can leverage the new Python capabilities in NiFi 2.x.  We will need to find ways to reduce the overall size more as we go.

Ok.  The workflow needed approval to run again so just clicked that.  Meanwhile if we can get @mattyb149 @MikeThomsen to weight in or merge that would be great.  Given all the discussion it seems all are good so with that understanding I'll plan to merge tomorrow if things build fine and nobody has alternative input.

I think the last commit is not needed since the original solution contains null check in every `convert` implementation. The only issue could be if a new implementation would be added without a null check but it is very unlikely.
For now I just rebased against the main branch (I hope I did it correctly). Going through the changes to be more consistent with the naming.
Changes look good.  Letting local build wrap up and assuming that plus github checks run well i'll merge soon.
@gresockj Given your parameter context work is this something you can look at for merging?
OK, naming consistency should be better now

Full clean build with contrib check good.  And Github CI looking great.
Reviewed each changed file all looks good.  Some of the changes in files seemed massive due to perhaps whitespace but doesn't seem worth delaying this further.
Ran a series of tests using system properties.  Environment variables. Parameter contexts.  Looking each up either directly in the processor properties of UpdateAttribute or via parameter context lookup.  All worked as expected.

Great work Pierre.  This is a massive PR.  But dont want to delay it further as it will impact many things going into 2.x from here out.  This one is so expansive it likely starts to really make the break betweeen 2.x and 1.x.

Other notable changing the scope from VARIABLE to ENVIRONMENT will surely make 1.x processors not run on 2.x but I think we're likely well into needing people to rebuild for 2.x anyway a thing. 

+1 merging to main

Thanks @joewitt and @exceptionfactory . I did some light testing. I was able to verify that it started up as expected running Java 21 and that Python is installed. Unfortunately, though, it does not uncomment the line in nifi.properties needed in order to enable Python processors. Probably should get that line uncommented in the docker image. Otherwise, all looks good to me.
@ChrisSamo632 making this processor record based is something I have been working on and have mostly finished, I have some validation message handling to finish and unit tests.
Thanks for catching this @turcsanyip, I'll be more careful next time! Merging

OK, I won't notify you again about this release, but will get in touch when a new version is available. If you'd rather skip all updates until the next major or minor version, let me know by commenting `@dependabot ignore this major version` or `@dependabot ignore this minor version`.

If you change your mind, just re-open this PR and I'll resolve any conflicts on it.
Merged to `main` as is, and I changed jgit version to `5.13.2.202306221912-r` for the 1.x support branch.

Thanks for the update @joewitt . Looks good to me. Was able to bring it up, pointing to my local branch's `nifi-nar-bundles/nifi-py4j-bundle/nifi-python-test-extensions/src/main/resources/extensions` directory as a mount and it successfully started up and allowed me to start using Python processors. +1 will merge to main.
@r-vandenbos Do you have a NIFI ticket for your work that I could read up on?
@dan-s1 apologies I didn't create one as I did the work a couple of hours after finding the issue. I will create one today / tomorrow or I can just use yours?

@r-vandenbos My use case has to incorporate the ability to view the document as one document of JSON. I was very interested to have @markap14 suggestion incorporated whether to treat the flow file as a single JSON document or as JSON lines. Also how are you handling if one line (record) fails but all the other pass?

@levilentz Do you think you'll be able to knock out the rebase and @mattyb149 commentary?  This thing looks close and want to ensure we can get it across the finish line.  You've definitely hung in there quite well through a lot on this one!  Thanks

> @levilentz Do you think you'll be able to knock out the rebase and @mattyb149 commentary? This thing looks close and want to ensure we can get it across the finish line. You've definitely hung in there quite well through a lot on this one! Thanks

@joewitt  -- I am planning on getting this completed this evening. I just want to test removing jsr223 to make sure it works. If we can remove it, it will be a **huge** help for this (and my) project and should make O&M of this easier as groovy changes.
Awesome thanks!  Dont mean to rush you - just dont want to let this linger given how much effort you put in plus how much harder i made it with the java 21/groovy updates :). Thanks

@ChrisSamo632 Did you mean to actually make these records? I do not think JsonTreeReader iis needed here, Jackson has  `JsonMapper` which could allow for iteration of all the JSON objects thereby allowing for validating each object.

> @ChrisSamo632 Did you mean to actually make these records? I do not think JsonTreeReader iis needed here, Jackson has `JsonMapper` which could allow for iteration of all the JSON objects thereby allowing for validating each object.

Whether a RecordReader is used/needed here is a question for the implementation - what I'm getting at is the need to iterate through all Objects within the FlowFile - typically, that's done with a Reader in most Processors, but it doesn't *have* to be done that way here.

One option would be to use a Reader (which means we could have a file format other than JSON as input) then convert to JSON as needed within the processor in order to validate with a JSON Schema (instead of an Avro Schema as currently done in `ValidateRecord`). But that's maybe going too far/not the use case we're needing to address here. Yes, another option is to use a `JsonMapper` (which is basically what the JsonTreeReader is doing, right?) to iterate through the Objects to validate each in turn.

If `ValidateJson` is updated, then an option will indeed be needed to `Validate Whole` or `Validate Each` (whatever you want to call the options). Again, my suggesiton would be to look at `ValidateRecord` for how it separates the Record-based output to `valid` and `invalid` relationships depending upon whether they meet the defined schema.

@ChrisSamo632 ValidateRecord allows for splitting up the flowfile and sending records to both the valid and invalid relationships. That is now what we wanted necessarily in our use case but I am not sure how NIFI would like to implement this. We were looking for pass whole file or fail whole file even if one JSON line fails. I would think this would complicate the current logic of ValidateJson.
Also this processor should only take JSON as JSON schema is meant to validate JSON and has the ability to confirm more than just field and type checking as the Avro schema does.

> JSON schema is meant to validate JSON and has the ability to confirm more than just field and type checking as the Avro schema does.

That'd be an argument (from my perspective) to use JSON Schema to validate other types of data as well. JSON Schema is obviousl written with JSON validation being the main aim, but there's no real reason (that I'm aware of) that it couldn't be used to do the same thing for other data formats. NiFi users could then use JSON Schemas (and/.or Avro Schemas) to validate FlowFile content rather than having to use the `ScriptedValidateRecord` processor, for example

But, again, that's probably more of a stretch than what's needed here/now, and one to consider for the future. Splitting the output to `valid`/`invalid` would follow the same pattern as for `ValidateRecord`, so would seem to make sense for consistency. There might be other patterns the community wich to adopt instead though

@joewitt @markap14 @exceptionfactory Can you please share what you feel this processor should do? I wanted to use @markap14 original idea to have a property whether to support JSON lines or not. After that should this processor be patterned after ValidateRecord as @ChrisSamo632 suggested or not i.e. allowing for splitting up the flowfile? Thank you!

@dan-s1 note that in my original comment here, I actually suggested a new processor, e.g. `ValidateJsonRecord`, which would be an option to provide alternative functionality

But I'd also be mindful to not introduce more processors/functionality unnecessarily, as it could lead to more confusion for users

The use cases to address would appear to be:
1. Validate an entire FlowFile against a JSON Schema
2. Validate every JSON Object (or Record in standard NiFi parlance) from within a FlowFile against a JSON Schema - the suggestion is to do this for all Objects and provide a much information as possible as the result, e.g. split the FlowFile content (as appropriate) between `valid` & `invalid` relationships

Hello Team I am currently facing the hyphen ( dash ) issue in Apache Avro schema that we use along with Schema Registry for deserialization.   Few field names in our Avro Schema contain dashes. I need help to locate the above proposed solution i.e. how to use the AvroSchemaRegistry and the boolean value to disable the validation. I assume its not a property in the Confluent Schema Registry. Can someone share any resource which shows how to bring in AvroSchemaRegistry in picture with the Avro Schema so that I can set the property to disable the field name validation somwhere.

We Specify the .avsc files in aspring boot microservice which after compiled generated the corresponging POJOS that we use in other micro-services (spring boot apps). We do not have any other Java implementation to manipulate the avro schemas.
Most probably not all copied config files are required by Python ITs, to be cleaned up in scope of follow-up: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/NIFI-12133
Please file a JIRA at https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/NIFI. Any PR must be linked to a JIRA issue.

@ChrisSamo632 Your suggestion of a new processor e.g. `ValidateJsonRecord` seems to be similar to what NIFI has already for Jolt, `JoltTransformJSON` which handles single documents and `JoltTransformRecord` which can handle multiple  documents.  Could then we have `ValidateJson` handle single documents and `ValidateJsonRecord` handle JSON lines?  Though I would have to wonder if moving forward in 2.x does NIFI want to support both `JoltTransformJSON` and `JoltTransformRecord` or only `JoltTransformRecord`?

Hi @exceptionfactory ! Thank you very much for the effort you did put on the review! I added some changes. Also answering your question:

`
One general question is whether we should switch the configuration property or keep the json.file property. Relying on the json.file property name would simplify upgrading without having to change property values. On the other hand, it is a simple manual change that seems reasonable. Thoughts?
`
I was thinking on this myself as well, but I deciced to use the original property name without remarking the file format because from now on, this should be the default format thus it looks both unnecessary and confusing to highlight this.
@joewitt I created this PR to add this Nifi OIDC configuration I thought it was tricky to configure it, though. I believe it helps someone!
thanks @marcelo225 checking it out now
Cool - looks helpful.  Merged.  Thanks
@joewitt @MikeThomsen @mattyb149 I have updated the code with your suggested changes, and they are working great! Let me know if you have any other changes.
the reordered import changes are a bit brutal in terms of signal to noise ratio.  Fixable?

> the reordered import changes are a bit brutal in terms of signal to noise ratio. Fixable?

Well, that is disappointing :( I am on a new laptop, and I guess I didn't get all of my IntelliJ settings mapped over. Just updated my settings so that it properly organizes the imports in the future. Unfortunately I am not sure how it can be fixed at this point without a massive amount of effort, searching through each modified file and manually opening it and organizing imports. We could, perhaps, in a follow-on PR, issue an "Organize Imports" in IntelliJ at the root level so that we have them all in the desired order...
Should I comment on the fact that literally everything failed due to contrib check or you got that ;)

full clean build with contrib check all good.  nifi starts up and does its thing as normal.  will let CI run then happy to merge.

Disabling it prevents users from getting to benefit from the power of content archiving (click to content before/after transformations).  90% increases odds of filling.  50% means many users simply dont get to run.  Disabling means they dont get to use a key feature.  I am fine with us changing this as we go.  But this seems a reasonable next step.
Thanks @joewitt that's a really good idea. +1 will merge.
Yeah, I agree, I think 3 hours / 90% is reasonable for running locally, which is generally what our defaults are for. +1 will merge.
@exceptionfactory Does that mean I have to create a branch off of support/nifi-1.x with my change and then create a new PR or does it just mean editing this PR with the new target branch?

@r-vandenbos I would like to go with @ChrisSamo632 suggestion of two processors. Can you please submit a ticket for your work but creating a new processor that can handle records and I will fix ValidateJson with @markap14 original suggestion of a property. As I mentioned before, this seems to align with what NIFI already has for Jolt `JoltTransformJSON` which handles single documents and `JoltTransformRecord` which can handle multiple documents. Hopefully now there will be ValidateJson and ValidateJsonRecord.

> @exceptionfactory Does that mean I have to create a branch off of support/nifi-1.x with my change and then create a new PR or does it just mean editing this PR with the new target branch?

@dan-s1 Changing the base branch of this pull request to `support/nifi-1.x` should be sufficient provided that is does not result in bringing in any additional commits. If it does result in additional commits, then you will need to create a new pull request with this specific commit, from the `support/nifi-1.x` branch. Thanks!

@exceptionfactory It resulted in other commits so I created a new branch off of support/nifi-1.x and I will create another PR. Interesting I am doing the build with the contrib profile and there was a Checkstyle violation on another piece of code SplitJson

> @exceptionfactory It resulted in other commits so I created a new branch off of support/nifi-1.x and I will create another PR. Interesting I am doing the build with the contrib profile and there was a Checkstyle violation on another piece of code SplitJson

Thanks @dan-s1. Feel free to close this pull request when you have the new one submitted.
The cherry-pick to 1.x was kinda messy. Looks like `CONNECTION_POOL` was moved to `RedisUtils` in another commit. I'll try to chase that down later.

How do the other apps work with an invalid schema? If you need to "normalize" the names so the schema is valid (and the data is not already in Avro format), I wrote a [blog post ](https://funnifi.blogspot.com/2023/08/change-record-field-names-with.html)showing how to do that.
commit message should reference NIFI-12142 not NIFI-12147
(Manually closed, github isn't tracking support/nifi-1.x)

Thanks @MikeThomsen and @gresockj 

I was able to resolve the cherry-pick to `support/nifi-1.x`, it was because there is one change for a new redis processor that was not back-ported there, so worked around that.
Reviewing the system test failures after several attempts...

It appears that system tests have failed on the main branch from the last several runs:

https://github.com/apache/nifi/actions/workflows/system-tests.yml?query=branch%3Amain
Rebased and fixed checkstyle warning

If using a validator such as a file exists validator and the value comes from a flowfile attribute expression evaluation the processors shows as valid even if the underlying dir doesn't exist.  That makes sense since it cannot know until runtime.  However, at runtime when it evaluates the value it appears to find the directory does not exist and automatically routes to 'failure' without executing the processors code.  *I think*.  Because I see data going to failure and I find this interesting log output

`2023-09-30 16:59:27,979 INFO [NiFiGatewayConnection Thread for UpdateAttributeFileLookup temp-component-UpdateAttributeFileLookup] o.a.n.p.processor.FlowFileTransformProxy PythonProcessor[type=UpdateAttributeFileLookup, id=461e6905-2771-360b-224c-b0cdec945c70] The directory  does not exist`

It should probably rollback rather than route to failure or at least make clear it is choosing to route to failure at a framework level...

Actually that printed output is from my custom processor and reflects a bug I had.  What I think the python/framework is doing is if no relationship is selected it is auto selecting 'failure'.  If that is true we should rollback.  Still looking into it

Reading FlowFileTransformProxy it appears that if you route to failure it removes the flowfile created/modified by the script and instead routes the original to failure.
